etymologies: late Middle English declinson, from Old French declinaison, from decliner ‘to decline’. The change in the ending was probably due to association with words such as ascension

definitions: (in the grammar of Latin, Greek, and other languages) the variation of the form of a noun, pronoun, or adjective, by which its grammatical case, number, and gender are identified.
shortDefinitions: (in grammar of Latin, Greek, and certain other languages) variation of form of noun, pronoun, or adjective

definitions: the class to which a noun or adjective is assigned according to the manner of this variation

examples.text: this declension involves only two endings, a nominative and an oblique

shortDefinitions: class to which noun or adjective is assigned according to manner of this variation

definitions: a condition of decline or moral deterioration

examples.text: the declension of the new generation

shortDefinitions: condition of decline or moral deterioration
